items.name: Molly Elizalde
items.shortBio: Writer and Editorial Assistant at Cond√© Nast Traveler
items.bio: Molly is an editorial assistant at Traveler. She writes about art and culture.

items.hed: How to Decorate Your Home Like a Parisian
items.dek: French interior designer Jean-Louis Deniot finds inspiration around every corner: on a trip to Morocco, or a nightclub at 3 a.m.‚Äîeven in "a pile of trash with an amazing color behind it." Deniot has an exceptional talent for marrying his clients‚Äô personal aesthetics with his own neoclassical-cum-mod taste. Just look at his two most recent endeavors: He's been busy creating a line of furniture in collaboration with British upholsterer [George Smith](http://www.georgesmith.com/) and publishing his first book, *[Jean-Louis Deniot: Interiors](http://www.rizzoliusa.com/book.php?isbn=9780847843329)* (Rizzoli), which was released in September. We sat down with the designer to get his expert tips on how to decorate in his signature French style. Here, we take a detailed look at four of his projects, each in different locations: the Left Bank of Paris, the Right Bank of Paris, the French countryside, and the United States.

items.title: Left Bank
items.caption:
*It‚Äôs in this insistently romantic quartier, among the bookshops, galleries, and antiquaries, that Jean-Louis Deniot has situated his office. It‚Äôs among the art schools and university that he finds 20th-century treasure for his interiors.* ‚ÄîDiane Dorrans Saeks in *Jean-Louis Deniot Interiors*

When you're in the presence of large volumes, brushed oak paneling and contrasting ebony doors will bring instant warmth and texture, Deniot says.
items.credit: All photos courtesy Jean-Louis Deniot; photography by Xavier BeÃÅjot; art direction by Paul Mckevitt

items.title: Left Bank
items.caption: The artwork doesn‚Äôt have to be systematically pleasing or welcoming.

items.title: Left Bank
items.caption: Juxtaposing two similar kinds of graphics‚Äîhere the straw marquetry fan pattern on the long chest echoes the blurry harlequin shape of the wall upholstery‚Äîcan bring a room together.

items.title: Right Bank
items.caption:
*Fine art, connoisseurship, antiques, fashion, and haute couture are signatures of the Right Bank.* ‚ÄîDiane Dorrans Saeks in *Jean-Louis Deniot Interiors*

Give a room a cocoon-like feeling by covering walls with light leather.

items.title: Right Bank
items.caption: Bedroom alcoves can provide a protective feel in addition to being great storage solutions.

items.title: Right Bank
items.caption: Apply a different treatment to each wall of a room; it will create volume.

items.title: Right Bank
items.caption: The same ideas can be developed into various finishes without looking repetitive, predictable, or boring.

items.title: Paris Weekends: French Country House
items.caption:
*Friday afternoons it‚Äôs time to pack the car boot with Champagne, design magazines, cashmere sweaters, and Wellingtons. A one-hour car trip takes the designer and friends into the former hunting grounds of Louis XV. It‚Äôs an exceptionally lush region, with noble ancient oaks that are considered national treasures, and castles and palatial stables that bespeak past grandeur.* ‚ÄîDiane Dorrans Saeks in *Jean-Louis Deniot Interiors*

In this room, most of the surface is clad in wool (wool rug, wool drapes, etc.): a great material for maximum soundproofing.

items.title: Paris Weekends: French Country House
items.caption: In this image, there are six different patterns juxtaposed on top of one another. This gives a great sense of layering without looking busy.

items.title: Paris Weekends: French Country House
items.caption: I like tablescapes to look like one composition, using one range of colors.

items.title: French Style in America
items.caption:
*In Chicago, French style translates for a Francophile family to rooms and decor that suggest a mansion on the Right Bank. ... Meanwhile, in a Beverly Hills estate, a historically significant residence, designed by architect-to-the-stars Paul Revere Williams, gains luster with a fresh floor plan, a new French accent.* ‚ÄîDiane Dorrans Saeks in *Jean-Louis Deniot Interiors* 

An abstract painting or any kind of large-scale contemporary photography will give a room the illusion of added space.

items.title: French Style in America
items.caption: When rooms are asymmetrical in their structure or furniture layout, I play with large screens to balance out the space.

items.title: French Style in America
items.caption: The only time I used bright colors‚Äîmalachite or emerald green‚Äîis inside dark rooms. Here the color provides excitement without being overly aggressive.

items.socialTitle: How to Decorate Your Home Like a Parisian
items.seoTitle: French Designer Jean-Louis Deniot on How to Decorate Your Home Like a Parisian
items.seoDescription: We sat down with French designer Jean-Louis Deniot to get his expert tips on how to decorate in his signature French style.

items.name: Jinna Yang
items.shortBio: Jinna Yang is a lifestyle photographer and the Founder/Creative Director of [Grease and Glamour](http://greaseandglamour.com/), a visual destination serving up endless travel inspiration.
items.bio: In April 2013, lifestyle photographer Jinna Yang quit her full-time fashion job to travel the world. She started sharing stories of her adventures on [Grease and Glamour](http://greaseandglamour.com/), helping inspire others to live life with purpose and follow their dreams. Founded in 2012, Grease and Glamour quickly became a platform for endless inspiration, showcasing some of the world's most beautiful destinations. Jinna‚Äôs work has been featured in Time Magazine, CNN Travel, Yahoo, BBC World Radio, and hundreds of other media outlets around the world.

items.hed: Travel For Better Skin: 5 Destinations With All-Natural Healing Perks
items.dek: These five places are beautiful, but they're also renowned for their skin-healing properties.
items.seoTitle: Travel For Better Skin: 5 Destinations With All-Natural Healing Perks
items.seoDescription: These five places are beautiful, but they're also renowned for their skin-healing properties.
items.socialTitle: Travel For Better Skin: 5 Destinations With All-Natural Healing Perks
items.socialDescription: These five places are beautiful, but they're also renowned for their skin-healing properties.
items.body:
##Pamukkale, Turkey

[#image: /photos/540fc26c17e4b1f634eefa59]||||||

Known as the ‚Äúcotton castle‚Äù in Turkish, Pamukkale‚Äôs hot springs have been used as a spa since the second century BC. The waterfalls end in naturally white pools. The calcium-infused waters benefit the eyes and skin, and visitors have gone there seeking relief from high blood pressure, kidney stones, and asthma.

##Safaga, Egypt

[#image: /photos/54765e852a3d21fa285cad6e]||||||

The healing waters of Safaga, Egypt are locally referred to as the ‚Äúhealing zone‚Äù‚Äîthe salt concentration is 35 percent higher than that of most other seas. Bathing in the water reportedly improves circulation, while the black sand on the beach also contains minerals from the volcanic craters under the Red Sea, helping with arthritis and skin inflammations.

##Palia Kameni, Greece

[#image: /photos/54765e8dcbbd2620680ddd20]||||||

Palia Kameni, one of the two volcanic islands in the middle of the Santorini Caldera, is home to therapeutic sulfuric mud that is said to help treat skin conditions like acne, eczema, and psoriasis.

##Hells Gate, New Zealand

[#image: /photos/54765e7acbbd2620680ddd02]||||||

Hells Gate in Rotorua, New Zealand has been home to the healing mineral mud loved by the Ngati Rangiteaorere Tribe for more than 700 years. The mineral-rich mud has antibacterial, detoxifying, and moisturizing skin care benefits. 

##Japan

[#image: /photos/54765e792a3d21fa285cad50]||||||

You‚Äôll find *onsen*, or hot springs, throughout Japan. Most have healing capabilities, depending on the minerals contained in the springs. Depending on your needs, there are onsen rich in sulfur, sodium chloride, hydrogen carbonate, or iron‚Äîthey‚Äôre said to heal aches, pains, menstrual pain, and cardiovascular and digestive issues, as well as various skin diseases.

items.name: Matt Hranek
items.shortBio: Matthew Hranek is a contributing editor at Conde Nast Traveler.
items.bio: Matthew Hranek is a full time traveller, explorer, eater, and drinker. He is also a part time photographer, film maker, blogger, contributing Conde Nast Traveler editor, and occasional TV host. Matthew has 20 years experience navigating airports, train stations, hotels, restaurants, and bars worldwide. Mostly on the road and with his ear to the ground, he is inspired by the old school as well as the new. He is constantly on the forage. Follow him on his blog, [The William Brown Project](http://www.thewilliambrownproject.com/).

items.dek: Packing is more than a mere function of traveling; it‚Äôs a creative process that can make or break your trip. Here‚Äôs how to be perfectly prepared for the destination ahead.
items.socialTitle: 10 Packing Mistakes to Avoid On Your Next Trip

items.title: __1. Using the wrong bag__
items.caption: My first order of business is the bag: Depending on the destination, I go with a duffle (Orvis Battenkill, pictured, and Filson are stand outs) or a roller (Rimowa, ZERO Halliburton, TUMI, and Eddie Bauer all make great models). And despite what others may recommend, I almost always check my bag‚ÄîI‚Äôd rather spare myself the maddening competition for overhead space and settle in.

items.title: __2. Overpacking__
items.caption: You always want to leave some packing space to bring more stuff home‚Äîbecause you will. Choose your luggage based on this: Take a bag that's big enough, but leave some room in it so you can accommodate those souvenirs and flea-market finds.

items.title: __3. Leaving the swimsuit behind__
items.caption: There is always a pool, hot tub, or sauna that is worth dipping into when you travel, regardless of climate. There is nothing worse than the scramble to find a suit when you are presented with the opportunity for a good soak or swim‚Äîespecially after a long flight.

items.title: __4. Ignoring items that do double duty__
items.caption: I never leave home without at least one cashmere sweater (mine is a V-neck). They‚Äôre warm and easily dress up the most casual outfit when needed. Furthermore, they make excellent impromptu travel pillows on long-haul flights.

items.title: __5. Not taking enough underwear__
items.caption: Packing for four days is not much different than packing for a week: everything can be recycled and worn more than once, except your underwear (I hope). My favorite is the Brooks Brothers boxer brief (pictured). One pair per day should do the job‚Ä¶unless you are battling some jungle intestinal parasite.

items.title: __6. Only packing light colors__
items.caption: Light colors show wear and soil the easiest so invest in some dark-colored items, specifically shirts. Denim is also a good choice for pants: It‚Äôs versatile, resilient, and can be dressed up or down. (The RRL Selvedge jean from Ralph Lauren, pictured, is a good choice.)

items.title: __7. Being underprepared for weather changes__
items.caption: Always check the weather for the week ahead while you‚Äôre packing and leave room for changes while you‚Äôre there. Pack a rain jacket along with a mix of cool- and warm-weather clothes that can be layered or worn separately.

items.title: __8. Not bagging your shoes__
items.caption: Most good brands include shoe bags upon purchase, so use them. They protect everything in your bag from being exposed to the street grime, sand, or dirt that ends up on well-traveled footwear. Plus, you can pack extras and use them to wrap fragile items you want to bring home.

items.title: __9. Packing too many options__
items.caption: It‚Äôs easy to get caught up in the idea of packing too many clothing options, but if you establish a uniform of sorts, you will get more mileage out of your items and can therefore pack more efficiently. Just stick to what you‚Äôre comfortable in and what looks good that can also be worn in different scenarios, from the business lunch to the hotel bar. For example, I always pack some type of blazer or jacket that can be dressed up with a knit tie or a pressed shirt.

items.title: __10. Carrying a bad attitude__
items.caption: The most savvy travelers know that anything can happen despite your best-laid plans, so pack some tolerance and good humor and be prepared to roll with the punches. Make lemonade out of lemons; lost or delayed luggage is a great excuse to add new items to your wardrobe.

items.seoDescription: Packing is more than a mere function of traveling; it‚Äôs a creative process that can make or break your trip. Here‚Äôs how to be perfectly prepared for the destination ahead.
items.socialDescription: Packing is more than a mere function of traveling; it‚Äôs a creative process that can make or break your trip. Here‚Äôs how to be perfectly prepared for the destination ahead.

fields.title: 6. Over-pack for your trip.
fields.caption: Cruise ship cabins are small‚Äîin some cases, very small. Check out the cruise ship [dress codes](http://cruiseline.com/bonvoyage/before-you-cruise/what-to-wear/what-to-wear-on-your-cruise), and pack exactly what you need. Then edit out anything you don‚Äôt _really_ need, such as extra shoes and alternate outfits, or risk feeling like the things you brought make your cabin feel claustrophobic. Plus, if you pack light enough, you can use a carry-on bag and not risk that your stuff will miss the ship.

items.shortBio: Hanya Yanagihara is the former editor-at-large at *Conde Nast Traveler.*
items.bio: Hanya Yanagihara is the former editor-at-large at *Conde Nast Traveler* and the author of the novels *The People in the Trees* and *A Little Life* (March 2015). She is currently deputy editor of T magazine.

items.hed: Where to Shop in Shanghai Now
items.dek: From local marketplaces to mega malls, Shanghai is among the best shopping cities in the world. Here's where to go.
items.seoTitle: Where to Shop in Shanghai Now
items.seoDescription: From local marketplaces to mega malls, Shanghai is among the best shopping cities in the world. Here‚Äôs where to go.
items.socialTitle: Where to Shop in Shanghai Now
items.socialDescription: From local marketplaces to mega malls, Shanghai is among the best shopping cities in the world. Here‚Äôs where to go.

items.caption: The must-go marketplace? Yu Yuan Gardens and Bazaar. Although a bit touristy, it's still worth it for its selection of everything from scarves and clothing to jewelry and knick-knacks (218 Anren St, Huangpu, Shanghai, +86 21 6326 0830).

Almost 6 miles from end to end, Nanjing Road tends to be separated into two sections: Nanjing East Road and Nanjing West Road. Here you‚Äôll find small shops and markets selling original jewelry, accessories, and food, as well as storefronts of larger more commonly known brands. From here, you can also visit Reel Mall, on Nanjing West Road, which is full of high end stores from both Chinese and International designers.

Art collectors shouldn‚Äôt miss the M50 Art Hub on Morgan Shan Road. The artist-run complex, which houses galleries such as ShanghART (50 Moganshan Rd, Putuo, Shanghai, +86 21 6359 3923, [shanghartgallery.com](http://shanghartgallery.com)) and Art Scene China (2/F, Bldg #4, 50 Morganshan Road, Shanghai, +86 21 6277 4940, [artscenechina.com](http://artscenechina.com)), is worth a visit for anyone interested in China‚Äôs contemporary art scene.

Shanghai is well known for its custom tailoring and designs. At W.W. Chan & Sons Tailor Ltd., you‚Äôll be able to construct an entire wardrobe from scratch. You can bring in photographs of styles you‚Äôre interested in, and then choose your own fabrics from the voluminous collection of sample books ( 528, 5/F, West Tower Shanghai Centre, 1376 Nanjing Road West, +86 21 6289 8682, [wwchan.com](http://wwchan.com)).

Pearls are a local specialty, and Shanghai Pearl City stocks pearls in every size, shape, and hue. It can be a bit overwhelming, so you need to know what you‚Äôre looking for, but their prices are quite competitive so it‚Äôs well worth the trip (3721 Hongmei Lu, Shanghai, +86 21 6262 3851).

Founded in 2010, M.R.K.T. is full of architecture-inspired bags and accessories in clean, geometric concepts, all made of everything from vegan leather to felt, and produced in a rainbow of colors (741 Julu Rd, Jing'an, Shanghai, +86 21 5403 0791, [mrktstore.com](http://mrktstore.com)).

fields.name: Avery Matera
fields.shortBio: Avery Matera is a fashion and style writer born and bred in NYC.
fields.bio: Born and bred in NYC, Avery Matera is a fashion and style writer. In addition to her undying passion for this perfect concrete jungle, she lives for the beaches of Cape Cod and ski slopes of Tahoe. A striped shirt aficionado and lover of classic pajama sets, she will forever be on the hunt for the next eclectic bracelet to add to her collection.
